headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; CITY EDUCATION. New School-house in Yorkville--Remarks of S.S. Randell and Others. The Baptist Bible House--Opening Ceremonies. New-York Horticuitural Society--The State Fair. New-York Consolidated Stage Company. Suicide by Hanging. The Harlen Railroad--Veto of Mayor Westervelt. Court of General Sessions. HIGHWAY ROBBERY. GRAND LARCERIES. A RIVER THIEF. PLEAS OF GUILTY. SENTENCED. Commercial Espionage. MARINE COURT.

docs.lead_paragraph: The public opening of the new School house No. 27, in Eighty-seventh-street, took place on Monday. The City Superintendents, Messrs. RANDALL and McKEEN, Mr. GILBERT, Chief of the Board, Alderman WALKEMAN, ex-Alderman TIEMAN, the school officers, and a large number of visitors, parents and citizens, were present.

docs.lead_paragraph: The following, from a letter of our Washington Correspondent, concerning an event which has occurred since it was written and which then seemed to be impending, will be read with interest: WASHINGTON, Sunday, Sept. 10, 1854.

headline.main: The Exposure of Telegraphic Dispatches at Augusta.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Augusta (Georgia) Chronicle, of the 6th, publishes a card from Mr. W. O. CARPENTER, the chief operator in the telegraph office there, orculpating himself from having violated confidence by scattering copies of old telegraphic dispatches in the street.

docs.lead_paragraph: The academic term of the Institution for the Blind, in Ninth-avenue, corner of Thirty-third-street, commenced yesterday, and nearly all of the pupils who took advantage of the recent vacation to visit their friends have returned. This Institution, which is supported by the State, has connected with it at the present time, 180 blind persons of different ages and sexes.

headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; Crime in New-York in Six Months. Semi-Annual Report of the Chief of Police. POLICE DEPARTMENT. Semi-Annual Report of the Chief of Police Crime in New-York in Six Months Uauthorized Imprisonment in the Sixth Ward Station-House. Power of Police Justices. GENERAL ORDER. THE MURDER IN ALBANY-STREET. Appointment of Police Captains.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Semi-Annual Report of the Chief of Police, Mr. MARSHALL, was presented in the Board of Aldermen, last evening. The Report is as follows: Hon. JACOB A. WESTERVELT--Sir : In conformity with the provisions of the Police Law, I herewith present to you a report showing the operations and condition of the Police Department for the six months ending June 30, 1854.

docs.lead_paragraph: Incendiary Attempts in Brooklyn. A block of buildings located on Hamilton-avenue, near Court-street, owned by Dr. TOWNSEND, were fired yesterday morning in the basement of one of the houses unoccupied, but it was discovered in season to prevent a conflagration.

headline.main: NEW-YORK CITY.; The Steamer Washington Smugglers--Further Testimony in the Case. Robbery at a Railroad Depot. A Magistrate and Police Captain in Trouble. A WOMAN ASSAULTING A DRINKER.. NO ROBBERY. NUTS AND WASHERS. Polie Justices--Sunday Work--Extra Pay. SUPREME COURT--SPECIAL TERM--SEPTEMBER. SEPTEMBER SESSION The Courts. PORTER-HOUSE BROKEN INTO. Court of General Sessions. ANOTHER WATCH GONE.

headline.main: GOSSIP.; The Talk of the Literary Circles Abroad.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ruskin on the Crystal Palace. The Athenceum digests Mr. Ruskin's pamphlet on The Opening of the Crystal Palace. It says: It may now be laid down as little short of an acknowledged dogma, that Mr. Ruskin can be no more expected to write a page without some allusion to Turner or Venice than Don Quixote could utter three consecutive sentences without a mention of Palmerin of England, or Don Belianis of Greece.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Female Normal School of the Board of Education commenced its Semi-Annual Session at their Hall, corner of Grand and Elm-streets, on Saturday morning last at 9 o'clock--the session closing as usual at 2 P. M. The School is divided into five classes, A, B, C, D, E, and sub-divided into fourteen sections each under the care of a teacher.
